He understood the hardship that politics has on a family and the hard work and commitment that it requires.

The last months of my dad's life were not sad or terrifying, but filled with profound experiences, a series of moments more precious than I could have imagined.
He taught me more about humility, vulnerability and courage than he had taught me in my whole life.
Although he lived a full and complete life by any measure, the fact is he wasn't done.
He still had work to do.
He was so proud of where we had recently come as a nation.

And although I do grieve for what might have been, for what he might have helped us accomplish, I pray today that we can set aside this sadness and instead celebrate all that he was and did and stood for.
I will try to live up to the high standard that my father set for all of us when he said: The work goes on, the cause endures, the hope still lives and the dream shall never die.
